justification: All symptoms are commonly associated with food allergies, especially angioedema which is a severe allergic reaction.}, {diagnosis: Drug allergy
justification: Similar to food allergies, medications can also cause these symptoms, with angioedema being a red flag for a severe reaction.}, {diagnosis: Viral gastroenteritis (stomach flu)
justification: Diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and vomiting are classic symptoms, though nasal congestion is less common.}, {diagnosis: Parasitic infection (e.g., Giardia)
justification: These infections can cause gastrointestinal distress, and some can also lead to respiratory symptoms.}, {diagnosis: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) flare-up
justification: While less likely to cause nasal congestion, IBD can cause the other symptoms listed.}, {diagnosis: Appendicitis (early stages)
justification: May present with diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and vomiting initially, though typically progresses to severe pain.}, {diagnosis: Bowel obstruction (partial)
justification: Can cause similar gastrointestinal symptoms, but nasal congestion would be unusual.}, {diagnosis: Systemic mastocytosis
justification: A rare disorder that can cause flushing, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and in severe cases, angioedema.}, {diagnosis: Hereditary angioedema
justification: While rare, this genetic condition can cause recurrent episodes of angioedema along with abdominal symptoms.}, {diagnosis: Adverse reaction to a food additive or preservative
justification: Certain additives can trigger reactions in sensitive individuals, potentially causing these symptoms.}
